stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on implementing a new rideable 'soap bar' object. This involved programming its shrinking behavior, creating a custom bubble particle trail, and designing a corresponding 'oil slick' with a dynamic, iridescent visual effect that the soap will eventually clean up. He also discussed and showed concepts for a new 3D panoramic star select screen.

development_findings.summary: The team is designing a new star select screen. The current plan, based on Biobak's concept, is to use small, real-time 3D panoramas for each level to save ROM space and improve visual quality on emulators compared to static images.
development_findings.quote: Basically, each level is gonna have a very small panorama that shows the vibe of the level... If we have a pre-rendered 3D scene, it's going to be cheaper ROM-wise. And it's going to look better on emulator.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a new rideable 'soap bar' object that shrinks from the bottom up as the player rides it, eventually disappearing and throwing Mario forward.
Kaze created a custom particle system that is more efficient than the original SM64 engine's, as it avoids reloading the same texture for each individual particle.
development_findings.quote: I have my own particle system. The original particle system is really bad because it overloads the texture every time. So rendering 10 bubbles like this would load the bubble texture 10 times.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed a dynamic oil slick cleanup mechanic. The plan is to programmatically edit the texture's alpha mask in real-time as the player moves over it with the soap bar.
development_findings.quote: We could have a normal oil texture and then an alpha mask and if you go over the thing the alpha mask like slowly fills up... Delete the alpha and all the pixels he's touched. And make the pixels black.

development_findings.summary: To create an iridescent effect for an oil slick, Kaze implemented a shader-like effect in software that dynamically changes the vertex colors of the puddle based on the camera's angle.
development_findings.quote: I could just use the jaw and the pitch of the camera and the position of the vertex to generate a random hue and put it on here. That wouldn't be difficult.

development_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned fixing a bug from the original SM64 engine where players would be rejected from steep walls, allowing for more consistent wall jumping.
development_findings.quote: In Mario 64 on a wall like this, you can't jump on it. You will get rejected from it. But I fixed that. So now walls like this consistently just work.

development_findings.summary: Kaze was contacted by the creator of an influential, 20-year-old SM64 modding tool who is now developing a new version, though Kaze did not disclose the name of the tool or creator.
development_findings.quote: There is a guy that made a really, really useful tool 20 years ago. And he just wrote me telling me that he's making a new one. And that is super cool.

context_findings.summary: After receiving an aggressive message, Kaze speculates on the psychology of the sender, who was seemingly offended by Kaze's opinion on philosophy. He finds the situation both bizarre and amusing.
context_findings.quote: Philosophy is kind of stupid. I don't think even the worst philosopher deserves this response. I mean, I don't know. Maybe the man's just very passionate.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states his design principle that his fan games are self-contained and do not require knowledge of his previous work, believing it makes them more accessible.
context_findings.quote: My stories don't connect when I make remakes. Making your story connected to your other fan games that probably a lot of people that play this new fan game haven't played. It's just kind of bad if you ask me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze goes on a lengthy, humorous rant about the non-intuitive way American microwaves interpret number inputs for time, contrasting `100` (1 minute) with `90` (90 seconds).
context_findings.quote: If you type in 61 on a microwave in America. Your food goes shorter, it goes longer than if you type in 100. Isn't that fucked up? How is 100 less than 61 on a microwave?

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains his philosophy for the game's final level, prioritizing an 'epic feel' and accessibility over extreme difficulty.
context_findings.quote: The final puzzle level... It's not going to be anything too difficult because people need to be able to beat it. It's going to feel epic, but it's not going to be super difficult.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares that he received a rape threat, noting it as a strange and rare event for a male creator compared to more common death threats.
context_findings.quote: I as a male have gotten a rape threat. That's insane. That's never happened to me before. This is like so rare to get that. Like death threats? Shoot, everyone's gotten some of those.

context_findings.summary: Kaze offers a cynical take on content creation in games like Roblox and Minecraft, comparing the dynamic to child labor and extending the analogy to the SM64 modding community.
context_findings.quote: I think child labor is what carries those games. Children make custom game modes that other children play and that's how the game like gets all the content. Mario 64 modding also lives on child labor in a way.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a concept for a new star select screen, featuring a small 3D panorama for each level, which Kaze preferred over his own initial attempt.
biobak.quote: Biobak had some pretty cool ideas. I've already experimented a bit with it, but I really don't like what I have so far... Biobak had this here, which I think works a lot better already.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested that the soap bubble particles should fade to white as they disappear, a feature Kaze then successfully implemented.
biobak.quote: Now it goes from normal to white. This is what Biobak has asked for.

biobak.summary: Kaze specifically seeks Biobak's approval on the final iridescent oil slick effect, indicating a collaborative relationship where Biobak provides aesthetic direction.

zeina.summary: Zeina was mentioned as being at work and later appeared in the stream chat, but had no direct development contributions mentioned in this stream.

key_stories.title: New Star Select Screen Concept
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak collaborated on a new concept for the star select screen. After Kaze's initial idea fell flat, he embraced Biobak's more ambitious concept of using a small 3D panorama for each level, choosing it for its visual appeal and technical advantages.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a new, more engaging star select screen than the original game's.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted a simple 2D drawing concept, which he deemed a failure ('it just looks terrible'). He then presented a concept from Biobak that was much more promising. He analyzed the technical trade-offs of using a 3D model versus a static image, concluding the 3D model was the better approach.
key_stories.outcome: The team decided to pursue Biobak's concept of using small, real-time 3D panoramas for each level, which Kaze determined was superior both aesthetically and technically (ROM size, emulator quality).
key_stories.key_quote: Basically, each level is gonna have a very small panorama that shows the vibe of the level... Biobak had this here, which I think works a lot better already.

key_stories.title: The Iridescent Oil Slick Effect
key_stories.summary: To make an oil slick visually appealing, Kaze engineered a custom software-based shader effect. He programmed the puddle's colors to shift dynamically based on the camera's angle, creating a unique iridescent look that the team was happy with.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a visually interesting oil slick that can be dynamically cleaned up, avoiding a boring, static texture.
key_stories.process: The team wanted a special effect for an oil slick. Kaze initially considered a simple reflective surface but found it technically challenging. An idea for a rainbow, iridescent effect was proposed. Kaze then translated this idea into a technical solution, using camera and vertex data to manipulate colors in real-time. He iterated on the texture, color saturation, and speed of the effect until it looked right.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a dynamic, iridescent oil slick by programming a system to shift its vertex colors based on camera angle. The effect was approved by Biobak and is ready for the cleanup mechanic to be implemented.
key_stories.key_quote: So you want me to map different... just the camera angle or also the vertex position? Because I could just use the jaw and the pitch of the camera and the position of the vertex to generate a random hue and put it on here.

key_stories.title: Creating the Bubble Particle Trail
key_stories.summary: Kaze went through a detailed process of creating a bubble particle effect for the soap bar. This involved debugging his particle system, creating custom textures, and implementing a specific fade-to-white visual request from Biobak, ultimately resulting in a polished effect.
key_stories.challenge: To create a trail of bubble particles for the rideable soap bar that looks good and performs well within the N64's limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented basic particles but they didn't appear. He debugged the particle system flags. He then created a custom bubble texture in GIMP. Biobak requested they fade to white, which Kaze struggled to implement with the material settings before finding a solution with `nthcolor`. He then fine-tuned the particle alpha, quantity, and spawn logic to achieve the final look.
key_stories.outcome: After significant debugging and iteration, Kaze created a satisfying bubble effect with a custom texture, a fade-to-white effect requested by Biobak, and a high particle count made possible by his custom particle engine.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this is hopeless because it always does that... Okay, this looks really good now. I like this a lot.
